H0.text: Specific heat is the amount of heat required to raise a single mass unit of a substance by a single temperature unit.

H1.text: Temperature variation is the amount of heat required to raise a single mass unit of a substance by a single temperature unit.

H2.text: Specific gravity is the amount of heat required to raise a single mass unit of a substance by a single temperature unit.

H3.text: Solitary heat is the amount of heat required to raise a single mass unit of a substance by a single temperature unit.

A4.text: the specific heat capacity (symbol c) of a substance is the amount of heat that must be added to one unit of mass of the substance to cause an increase of one unit in its temperature
